moves.1. e4 c5 2. Bc4: Allows future tempo gain with d5
moves.2... Nf6 3. e5 d5 4. Bb5+: White does not want to give up the bishop pair
moves.4... Bd7 5. Be2 Ng8: leaving white with a pawn weakness
moves.8. f4: creates further weaknesses along the a8-h1 diagonal
moves.8... f5: so I aim to control that diagonal
moves.9. Ng3 e6: Somewhat like a mirror image Benoni
moves.10... Nc6 11. Ng1e2 O-O-O: Since Black castles kingside in a normal Benoni, I thought it was appropriate to castle queenside in this mirror image Benoni
moves.13. O-O: this will be an opposite side castling attacking position
moves.14... Nge7: aiming to put more pressure on the central dark squares with Ng6 after g5
moves.16. fxg5 Ng6: Instead of taking on g5, I invite gxh6
moves.17. Bxc6: White removes one of the controllers of e5, but is giving up good bishop, strengthening my light-squared bishop
moves.17... Bxc6: Now I control the whole diagonal
moves.18... hxg5: now threats along the h-file can become an issue
moves.20... Nxe5: giving up exchange for bishop pair
moves.21. Bxh8 Rxh8: Bishops can often be better than rooks in the opening phase, because the rooks lack space to maneuver. They are also especially good in these opposite side castling positions, because the bishops can perform defensive and offensive tasks at the same time. The Sicilian Dragon is a good example of that.
moves.22... Ng6: controlling f4 and also aiming for g2
moves.23... Bd6: battery along the b8-h2 diagonal, controlling f4, and attacking g3, bishops are very strong in these types of positions
moves.24... Nh4: clearing g-file and threatening to take g2
moves.25. Rfg1 Rg8: now g3 and g2 are both under fire,
moves.26. Qh6 Bxg3+ 27. Nxg3 Qxg3+ 28. Kf1 Bxg: White did not have enough time to start an attack of own
